CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 14 In particular , Guo et al. reported that OFETs based on a phthalimide - containing polythiophene exhibited hole mobilities of ∼ 0.2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions without optimization. 14 Thiophene imide has simple , compact , symmetric , and planar structure. It could promote intrachain and interchain interactions along and between coplanar polymer chains. Zhang et al. pioneered to use thiophene imide as a building block in conjugated polymers. 15,16 Later , thiophene imide homopolymers were synthesized. 17-19 Recently , polymer solar cells based on blends of copolymers of thiophene imide and benzodithiophene 20-23 or cyclopentadithiophene 24 with soluble fullerene derivatives PC71BM or PC61BM exhibited PCEs of 3-6.8 % . Wudl et al. reported low - bandgap conjugated polymers based on thiophene - fused phthalimide , i.e. , isothianaphthene imides ( 5 , Figure 1 ). 25,26 2,2 0 -Bithiophene-3,3 0 -dicarboximide ( BTI , 6 , Figure 1 ) with π-core planarity , antiparallel BTI packing , a short cofacial π-π distance of 3.43 Å , and a favorable solubilizing group orientation is a promising building block in n - type polymers. 27 Facchetti et al. reported that n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer exhibited a μ e of 1.1 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , I on / I off of 2 x 10^7 , and a high V th ( 75 V ) in vacuum after annealing process at 240 ° C. 27 The fused - ring system can maximize the π-orbital overlap by restricting intramolecular rotation in the oligomer and possibly to induce face - to - face π-stacking , facilitating charge transport through intermolecular hopping. On the other hand , the fused rings can make the polymer backbone more rigid and coplanar , therefore enhancing effective π-conjugation , lowering bandgap , and extending absorption. 28-31 Therefore , fused - ring building blocks are widely used in synthesis of conjugated polymers. 32-34 For example , the large planar benzodithiophene ( BDT ) unit has emerged as an attractive building block for conjugated polymers. 35 Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene ( 7 , Figure 2 ) with a curved structure prevents a fully conjugated pathway between substituents at the 2-and 6-positions. Hence , delocalization of the conjugated π-electron system along the copolymer backbone is disfavored by the incorporation of this unit. This increases the ionization potential of the polymer and is thus expected to improve air stability under operation. Additionally , compared to a single thiophene ring , it must be pointed out that due to the large resonance stabilization energy of BDT , the delocalization of electrons from the BDT unit into the backbone is less favorable than from the thiophene ring. As a result , a more stable copolymer with high performance can be obtained by using BDT as the core unit. OFETs based on a benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer manufactured on flexible substrate exhibited high hole mobility of 0.5 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 when the source-gate voltage is increased to 60 V.

Let's think step by step.

1. Phthalimide-containing polythiophene
2. Thiophene imide
3. Thiophene imide homopolymers
4. Isothianaphthene imides
5. 2,2 0 -Bithiophene-3,3 0 -dicarboximide (BTI)
6. Bithiophene imide homopolymer
7. Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene (BDT)
8. Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer

These are the material names mentioned in the paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. Phthalimide-containing polythiophene
2. Thiophene imide
3. Thiophene imide homopolymers
4. Isothianaphthene imides
5. 2,2 0 -Bithiophene-3,3 0 -dicarboximide (BTI)
6. Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene (BDT)
7. Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer

These are the material names explicitly mentioned in the paragraph. Other entities such as "OFETs," "building blocks," "soluble fullerene derivatives," and "n-type polymers" are not material names but rather types or categories of materials.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| --- |
| Phthalimide-containing polythiophene |
| Thiophene imide |
| Thiophene imide homopolymers |
| Isothianaphthene imides |
| 2,2 0 -Bithiophene-3,3 0 -dicarboximide (BTI) |
| Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene (BDT) |
| Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 14 In particular , Guo et al. reported that OFETs based on a phthalimide - containing polythiophene exhibited hole mobilities of ∼ 0.2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions without optimization. 14 Thiophene imide has simple , compact , symmetric , and planar structure. It could promote intrachain and interchain interactions along and between coplanar polymer chains. Zhang et al. pioneered to use thiophene imide as a building block in conjugated polymers. 15,16 Later , thiophene imide homopolymers were synthesized. 17-19 Recently , polymer solar cells based on blends of copolymers of thiophene imide and benzodithiophene 20-23 or cyclopentadithiophene 24 with soluble fullerene derivatives PC71BM or PC61BM exhibited PCEs of 3-6.8 % . Wudl et al. reported low - bandgap conjugated polymers based on thiophene - fused phthalimide , i.e. , isothianaphthene imides ( 5 , Figure 1 ). 25,26 2,2 0 -Bithiophene-3,3 0 -dicarboximide ( BTI , 6 , Figure 1 ) with π-core planarity , antiparallel BTI packing , a short cofacial π-π distance of 3.43 Å , and a favorable solubilizing group orientation is a promising building block in n - type polymers. 27 Facchetti et al. reported that n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer exhibited a μ e of 1.1 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , I on / I off of 2 x 10^7 , and a high V th ( 75 V ) in vacuum after annealing process at 240 ° C. 27 The fused - ring system can maximize the π-orbital overlap by restricting intramolecular rotation in the oligomer and possibly to induce face - to - face π-stacking , facilitating charge transport through intermolecular hopping. On the other hand , the fused rings can make the polymer backbone more rigid and coplanar , therefore enhancing effective π-conjugation , lowering bandgap , and extending absorption. 28-31 Therefore , fused - ring building blocks are widely used in synthesis of conjugated polymers. 32-34 For example , the large planar benzodithiophene ( BDT ) unit has emerged as an attractive building block for conjugated polymers. 35 Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene ( 7 , Figure 2 ) with a curved structure prevents a fully conjugated pathway between substituents at the 2-and 6-positions. Hence , delocalization of the conjugated π-electron system along the copolymer backbone is disfavored by the incorporation of this unit. This increases the ionization potential of the polymer and is thus expected to improve air stability under operation. Additionally , compared to a single thiophene ring , it must be pointed out that due to the large resonance stabilization energy of BDT , the delocalization of electrons from the BDT unit into the backbone is less favorable than from the thiophene ring. As a result , a more stable copolymer with high performance can be obtained by using BDT as the core unit. OFETs based on a benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer manufactured on flexible substrate exhibited high hole mobility of 0.5 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 when the source-gate voltage is increased to 60 V.

Let's think step by step.

1. OFETs: Organic Field-Effect Transistors
2. phthalimide-containing polythiophene: A type of polymer used in OFETs
3. thiophene imide: A specific type of imide compound, used as a building block in conjugated polymers
4. coplanar polymer chains: Chains of polymers that are flat and lie in the same plane
5. BTI: 2,2'-Bithiophene-3,3'-dicarboximide, a specific type of imide compound
6. n-channel OFET: An Organic Field-Effect Transistor that conducts negative charges
7. bithiophene imide homopolymer: A polymer made up of repeating bithiophene imide units
8. benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene: A specific type of dithiophene compound with a curved structure
9. BDT: Benzodithiophene, a large planar unit used as a building block for conjugated polymers
10. PC71BM and PC61BM: Fullerene derivatives used in polymer solar cells
11. PCEs: Power Conversion Efficiencies in polymer solar cells
12. isothianaphthene imides: A type of imide compound, specifically fused with phthalimide
13. Figure 1: A diagram or illustration mentioned in the text but not explicitly stated
14. Figure 2: Another diagram or illustration mentioned in the text but not explicitly stated
15. copolymers of thiophene imide and benzodithiophene or cyclopentadithiophene: Polymers made up of repeating units of thiophene imide and either benzodithiophene or cyclopentadithiophene
16. soluble fullerene derivatives: Fullerene compounds that are soluble in organic solvents
17. μ e: Mobility of electrons in a material
18. I on / I off: The ratio of the current with a voltage applied to the current with no voltage applied
19. V th : Threshold voltage in vacuum after annealing process
20. fused rings: Rings that are connected to each other within a molecule
21. oligomer: A small molecule made up of repeating units, used in the synthesis of polymers
22. intermolecular hopping: The transfer of charge between molecules
23. polymer backbone: The main structure of the polymer, to which the side groups are attached
24. effective π-conjugation: The extent of delocalization of electrons within the polymer backbone
25. bandgap: The energy difference between the conduction band and the valence band in a material
26. absorption: The process by which a material absorbs energy, such as light
27. Figure 3: Another diagram or illustration mentioned in the text but not explicitly stated.
28. fused-ring building blocks: Building blocks in the synthesis of conjugated polymers that contain fused rings
29. large planar benzodithiophene unit: A large, flat unit used as a building block for conjugated polymers
30. substituents: Atoms or groups of atoms attached to a main molecule
31. copolymer backbone: The main structure of the copolymer, to which the side groups are attached
32. resonance stabilization energy: The energy stabilization that occurs when electrons are delocalized over a larger area in a molecule
33. high performance: High efficiency or effectiveness in a material or device
34. Figure 4: Another diagram or illustration mentioned in the text but not explicitly stated.
35. flexible substrate: A substrate that can be bent or flexed without breaking.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. phthalimide-containing polythiophene: hole mobility (∼ 0.2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1)
2. thiophene imide
3. BTI (2,2'-Bithiophene-3,3'-dicarboximide): π-core planarity, antiparallel BTI packing, short cofacial π-π distance (3.43 Å), favorable solubilizing group orientation
4. isothianaphthene imides (isothianaphthene fused with phthalimide)
5. benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene: large planar unit, curved structure, increases ionization potential, improves air stability
6. benzodithiophene (BDT): large planar unit, prevents fully conjugated pathway between substituents, delocalization of electrons less favorable, emerges as an attractive building block for conjugated polymers
7. copolymers of thiophene imide and benzodithiophene or cyclopentadithiophene: PCEs (3-6.8 %)
8. fused rings: maximizes π-orbital overlap, induces face-to-face π-stacking, facilitates charge transport through intermolecular hopping, makes polymer backbone more rigid and coplanar, enhances effective π-conjugation, lowers bandgap, extends absorption
9. Figure 1, Figure 2, Figure 3, Figure 4: Diagrams or illustrations that may depict the structure or properties of materials.

These entities refer to the properties or structures of materials mentioned in the text.

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| --- |

| increases ionization potential of benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene |
| improves air stability of benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene |

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 14 In particular , Guo et al. reported that OFETs based on a phthalimide - containing polythiophene exhibited hole mobilities of ∼ 0.2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions without optimization. 14 Thiophene imide has simple , compact , symmetric , and planar structure. It could promote intrachain and interchain interactions along and between coplanar polymer chains. Zhang et al. pioneered to use thiophene imide as a building block in conjugated polymers. 15,16 Later , thiophene imide homopolymers were synthesized. 17-19 Recently , polymer solar cells based on blends of copolymers of thiophene imide and benzodithiophene 20-23 or cyclopentadithiophene 24 with soluble fullerene derivatives PC71BM or PC61BM exhibited PCEs of 3-6.8 % . Wudl et al. reported low - bandgap conjugated polymers based on thiophene - fused phthalimide , i.e. , isothianaphthene imides ( 5 , Figure 1 ). 25,26 2,2 0 -Bithiophene-3,3 0 -dicarboximide ( BTI , 6 , Figure 1 ) with π-core planarity , antiparallel BTI packing , a short cofacial π-π distance of 3.43 Å , and a favorable solubilizing group orientation is a promising building block in n - type polymers. 27 Facchetti et al. reported that n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer exhibited a μ e of 1.1 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , I on / I off of 2 x 10^7 , and a high V th ( 75 V ) in vacuum after annealing process at 240 ° C. 27 The fused - ring system can maximize the π-orbital overlap by restricting intramolecular rotation in the oligomer and possibly to induce face - to - face π-stacking , facilitating charge transport through intermolecular hopping. On the other hand , the fused rings can make the polymer backbone more rigid and coplanar , therefore enhancing effective π-conjugation , lowering bandgap , and extending absorption. 28-31 Therefore , fused - ring building blocks are widely used in synthesis of conjugated polymers. 32-34 For example , the large planar benzodithiophene ( BDT ) unit has emerged as an attractive building block for conjugated polymers. 35 Benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene ( 7 , Figure 2 ) with a curved structure prevents a fully conjugated pathway between substituents at the 2-and 6-positions. Hence , delocalization of the conjugated π-electron system along the copolymer backbone is disfavored by the incorporation of this unit. This increases the ionization potential of the polymer and is thus expected to improve air stability under operation. Additionally , compared to a single thiophene ring , it must be pointed out that due to the large resonance stabilization energy of BDT , the delocalization of electrons from the BDT unit into the backbone is less favorable than from the thiophene ring. As a result , a more stable copolymer with high performance can be obtained by using BDT as the core unit. OFETs based on a benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer manufactured on flexible substrate exhibited high hole mobility of 0.5 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 when the source-gate voltage is increased to 60 V.

Let's think step by step.

1. Hole mobility of OFETs based on phthalimide-containing polythiophene: 0.2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
2. PCEs of polymer solar cells based on blends of copolymers of thiophene imide and benzodithiophene or cyclopentadithiophene with fullerene derivatives: 3-6.8 %
3. μe of n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer: 1.1 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
4. Ion/Off ratio of n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer: 2 x 10^7
5. Thickness of gate dielectric in vacuum after annealing process: 75 V
6. π-π distance between antiparallel BTI packing: 3.43 Å
7. Bandgap of low-bandgap conjugated polymers based on thiophene-fused phthalimide (isothianaphthene imides): Not specified in the text
8. Solubilizing group orientation in BTI: Not specified in the text
9. Hole mobility of OFETs based on a benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer: 0.5 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
10. Source-gate voltage at which high hole mobility is achieved: 60 V

Note: The values provided in the text are approximate and may vary depending on the specific conditions and optimizations used in the experiments.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Hole mobility of OFETs based on phthalimide-containing polythiophene: 0.2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
2. PCEs of polymer solar cells: 3-6.8 %
3. μe of n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer: 1.1 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
4. Ion/Off ratio of n-channel OFET based on a bithiophene imide homopolymer: 2 x 10^7
5. Thickness of gate dielectric in vacuum after annealing process: 75 V
6. π-π distance between antiparallel BTI packing: 3.43 Å
7. Hole mobility of OFETs based on a benzo[2,1-b:3,4-b 0 ]dithiophene copolymer: 0.5 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1

These are the material properties that are explicitly mentioned in the text with their respective values. Other entities such as "hole mobilities of OFETs," "PCEs of polymer solar cells," and "μe of n-channel OFET" are not repeated, but they are implied and can be inferred from the context.
